description: venal +‎ -ity, from French vénalité or Latin vēnālitās, from vēnālis (“venal”), from vēnum.

entries.meaning: The fact or state of being for sale, especially with reference to bribes or corruption.
examples: As your spirited paper has declared war, not only against venality and despotism, but was intended to correct follies and abuses in private life, I hope the following will come within its useful plan.
